taxation.text: Under the new tax regime, the highest surcharge rate of 37% on income above INR 5,00,00,000 has been proposed to be reduced to 25%.
In the alternate tax regime under Section 115BAC, a revision to the basic exemption limit and the number of slabs has been proposed.
Further, income not derived or incidental to manufacturing or production of an article or thing shall be taxed at 22%.
The new tax regime under Section 115BAC is proposed to serve as the default regime.
Standard deduction from salary income and deduction from family pension is proposed to be extended to employees who opt for New Tax Regime.

A new section 115BAE is proposed to be inserted, which provides for reduced rate of tax of 15% (plus surcharge of 10% and cess) for Manufacturing co-operative societies established on or after April 1st, 2023, and commencing production on or before March 31st, 2024 [provided that specified incentives or deductions are not availed].
To avail a deduction under Section 10AA, the assessee must submit a return of income on or before the due date specified under Section 139(1).

Tax exemption under Section 10(46A) is proposed to be extended to ‘Non-corporate entities (Such as bodies, authorities, boards, trusts, or commissions), established by a Central or State Act for the purpose of providing housing, planning urban development, and regulating activities for the benefit of the public.
The exemption under Section 10(22B) for news agencies is proposed to be withdrawn.
This deduction is available in old as well as new tax regime.
A corresponding deduction shall be allowed under Section 80CCH for the same.

The threshold limits for presumptive taxation schemes under Section 44AD and Section 44ADA have been proposed to be increased to INR 3 crores and INR 75 lakhs respectively, provided at least 95% of receipts and payments are made through non-cash methods.
It is proposed to clarify that the benefit could also be in cash for taxability under section 28 of the Act and for tax deduction at source under section 194R of the Act.
The threshold limit for opting for the presumptive taxation scheme under section 44AD and section 44ADA is proposed to be increased to Rs.
The consequential amendments have been made under section 44AB to remove the tax audit requirement for persons opting for such presumptive schemes.
The gains derived from the transfer, redemption, or maturity of Market Linked Debentures shall be taxed at applicable rate as short-term capital gains under Section 50AA.
The provisions for tax on accreted income as specified in Section 115TD have been extended to trusts or institutions, if they fail to apply for re-registration.
In other words, the exemption shall be allowed if the return of income is furnished within the time allowed under Section 139(1) or Section 139(4) and not Section 139(8A).
The tax will be deducted either upon withdrawal or at the end of financial year.
Section 197 is proposed to be amended to include section 194LBA in its scope.
Sections 206AB and 206CCA have been amended to exclude certain persons from the scope who are not required to file a return of income and are notified by the government.
Section 155 is amended to solve a TDS mismatch problem.
It is proposed to amend section 271C and section 276B to provide for penalty and prosecution where deductor fails to ensure that tax has been paid under Section 194R, Section 194S and Section 194BA.
Distributions by business trusts to unit holders that are classified as debt repayment proposed to be taxed in the hands of unit holders.

Standard deduction from salary income and deduction from family pension is proposed to be extended to employees who opt for New Tax Regime.
The new tax regime under Section 115BAC is proposed to serve as the default regime.
Proposed amendments w.r.t.
To avail a deduction under Section 10AA, the assessee must submit a return of income on or before the due date specified under Section 139(1).
The exemption under Section 10(22B) for news agencies is proposed to be withdrawn.
A corresponding deduction shall be allowed under Section 80CCH for the same.
It is proposed to clarify that the benefit could also be in cash for taxability under section 28 of the Act and for tax deduction at source under section 194R of the Act.
It is proposed to amend Section 35D to remove the condition of activity in connection with these expenses to be carried out by a concern approved by the Board.
The consequential amendments have been made under section 44AB to remove the tax audit requirement for persons opting for such presumptive schemes.
In other words, the exemption shall be allowed if the return of income is furnished within the time allowed under Section 139(1) or Section 139(4) and not Section 139(8A).

Time provided for furnishing a return of income for claiming exemption by trusts or institutions under Section 10(23C) or Section 11 or Section 12 shall not include the time provided for furnishing an updated return.

Where any direction has been issued to give the effect to faceless schemes and e-proceedings before the expiry of the limitation period, the relevant provisions are proposed to be amended to empower Central Government to make amendments in such directions at any time by notification in the Official Gazette.

Section 72AA proposed to be amended to allow the carry forward of accumulated losses and unabsorbed depreciation in the case of the amalgamation of a banking company with another banking company within five years of the strategic disinvestment.
Section 197 is proposed to be amended to include section 194LBA in its scope.
Sections 206AB and 206CCA have been amended to exclude certain persons from the scope who are not required to file a return of income and are notified by the government.
Section 155 is amended to solve a TDS mismatch problem.

The proposed amendment to Section 92D shortens the deadline for submitting information or documents in tax proceedings related to international or domestic transactions from 30 days to 10 days, with an option to extend by another 30 days.
A corresponding amendment is proposed in sections 115UB, 56(2)(viib), 47(viiad), 10(4D) to provide that the AIFs should be regulated under the said regulation.
Section 88 is abolished to simplify the act and remove redundant provisions.

Generic Highlights.text: Finance Bill, 2023
The highest slab rate of 30% shall continue to apply to income above INR 15,00,000.
The threshold limit for total income eligible for rebate under Section 87A has been proposed to be increased from INR 5,00,000 to INR 7,00,000 for assessees opting for the new tax regime.
Provisions of Alternate Minimum Tax (AMT) and credit thereof shall not apply to cooperative societies opting for an alternate tax regime under Section 115BAE.

The threshold limit for opting for the presumptive taxation scheme under section 44AD and section 44ADA is proposed to be increased to Rs.
No tax shall be imposed on the transfer of capital assets in connection with the relocation of an offshore fund to an International Financial Services Centre (IFSC).
The deadline for this relocation has been extended to 31-03-2025.
The repayment of a loan or investment into the corpus will only be considered an application for charitable or religious purposes if it occurs within 5 years of the initial utilization.

The amendment in section 155 allows taxpayers to apply to the assessing Officer within two years of the financial year in which the tax was withheld.

Question 1.question: what is the impact of 2023 tax changes for income tax?
Question 1.statement:
The Finance Bill, 2023 proposes a new default tax regime under Section 115BAC, which includes a revision to the basic exemption limit and the number of slabs. Under the new tax regime, the highest surcharge rate of 37% on income above INR 5,00,00,000 has been proposed to be reduced to 25%. Furthermore, Sections 206AB and 206CCA have been amended to exclude certain persons from the scope who are not required to file a return of income and are notified by the government. The interest calculation for updated tax returns will be based on the difference between the assessed tax and the advance tax claimed in the earlier returns. Additionally, it is proposed to amend section 271C and section 276B to provide for penalty and prosecution where deductor fails to ensure that tax has been paid under Section 194R, Section 194S and Section 194BA. Lastly, the authorities can adjust the Income tax refunds with any outstanding tax due after written intimation only. 
Overall, the tax changes proposed in the Finance Bill, 2023 impact various aspects of income taxation, including the tax regime, surcharge rates, penalties and prosecution for non-compliance, and adjustments to tax refunds.

Question 3.question: what deductions are available in the new tax regime?
Question 3.statement:
In the new tax regime, standard deduction from salary income and deduction from family pension are proposed to be extended to employees who opt for it. This new regime serves as the default regime, and it proposes a revision to the basic exemption limit and the number of slabs. Additionally, the highest surcharge rate of 37% on income above INR 5,00,00,000 has been proposed to be reduced to 25%. The threshold limits for presumptive taxation schemes under Section 44AD and Section 44ADA have been proposed to be increased to INR 3 crores and INR 75 lakhs respectively, as long as at least 95% of receipts and payments are made through non-cash methods. It is also proposed to extend tax exemption under Section 10(46A) to non-corporate entities established by a Central or State Act for the purpose of providing housing, planning urban development, and regulating activities for the benefit of the public. 
Thus, standard deduction from salary income, deduction from family pension, and other revised deductions and exemptions are available under the new tax regime.
